Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment, reliance on documentary evidence vs. testimony, religious persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's testimony found credible but outweighed by documentary evidence
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) IRPA - well-founded fear of persecution
Basis_of_Claim: Religious persecution due to house church activities
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Perceived ability to practice religion in state-sanctioned patriotic churches
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection hearing, followed by judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to adequately analyze theological differences between house and patriotic churches
Review_Outcome: Board's decision upheld despite partial error
Evidence_Ignored: Significance of theological distinctions in religious practice
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution, reasonableness of decision
Application_Factor: Country conditions in Fujian Province, China
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Decision_Review_Issue: Did the Board err in credibility and evidence assessment?
Cause_of_Refusal: No serious risk of persecution found based on balance of probabilities
Evidentiary_Issues: Weight given to documentary evidence over personal testimony
Procedural_Fairness: Adequate opportunity to present case, though analysis lacked depth on key issue
Credibility_Issues: Testimony deemed credible but not determinative
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge to Board's interpretation of religious freedom in China
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review on judicial review
Omission_Type: Insufficient analysis of religious doctrine differences
